results.abstract: Mark Burnett, executive producer of television show Survivor, comments on his next big plan for reality television, rocketing the winner of a survivor competition to Russian space station Mir; Russian space agency it is considering ditching Mir (S)

headline.main: Fly That Winner To the Moon

results.snippet: Having turned ''Survivor'' into the biggest television draw this side of the Super Bowl, Mark Burnett, the show's executive producer, has no reason to suffer any crises of confidence.    So when word came last month that the aging Russian space...
results.lead_paragraph: Having turned ''Survivor'' into the biggest television draw this side of the Super Bowl, Mark Burnett, the show's executive producer, has no reason to suffer any crises of confidence. So when word came last month that the aging Russian space station Mir might come down from its anchor high above the earth long before Mr. Burnett could realize his next big plan for reality television, a contest to take a trip to Mir, he was far from fazed.

results.abstract: J Hoberman article on book Real Images: Soviet Cinema and the Thaw, by Josephine Woll, which explores Soviet cinema during 1960's; photo (M)

headline.main: From a Soviet Era That Dared to Defy The Ruling Dogma

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: REAL IMAGES: SOVIET CINEMA AND THE THAW (BOOK)

results.snippet: SYNONYMOUS with a season of worldwide cinematic upheaval, the era known as the Sixties saw new waves pound the shore from Japan to Brazil to Czechoslovakia. In the Soviet Union, however, the arrival of a Sixties cinema was complicated by an...
results.lead_paragraph: SYNONYMOUS with a season of worldwide cinematic upheaval, the era known as the Sixties saw new waves pound the shore from Japan to Brazil to Czechoslovakia. In the Soviet Union, however, the arrival of a Sixties cinema was complicated by an additional climactic shift known as the Thaw. Roughly coinciding with the reign of Nikita Khrushchev, this was the period of de-Stalinization, the Space Race and the Berlin Wall. On the cultural front, the Thaw inspired the new national idealism exemplified by the poets Yuri Yevtushenko and Andrei Voznesensky, and by the revelatory writings of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. It also allowed for the revitalization of a moribund film industry that once upon a time, in the silent 1920's, had been the most radical in the world, a resurgence demonstrated by the 25 hugely variegated features, known and unknown, in The Film Society of Lincoln Center series ''Revolution in the Revolution'' at the Walter Reade Theater through Nov. 30.
